Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Mini-LENS -- Operation of a Prototype Low-Energy Solar Neutrino Spectrometer Underground
Award.AbstractNarration:
Neutrinos from the Sun are ideal for studying neutrino-flavor phenomena and astrophysics. The Sun offers the greatest source flux of a pure electron-neutrino flavor coupled with high matter density in neutrino transport, long baseline, and low neutrino energies. An effective tool for new advances compares the luminosity of the Sun separately measured by neutrinos and photons that can uncover surprises in neutrino physics as well as astrophysics. A precision measurement of the neutrino-derived luminosity of the Sun is possible only by the detection of low-energy (<2 MeV) solar neutrinos that contain > 99.9% of the flux. One of the few answers to the experimental challenge of real-time low-energy neutrino detection is the indium-based Low Energy Solar Neutrino Spectrometer, LENS. It will uniquely provide a nearly background-free complete spectral image of solar neutrinos using Charged-Current-based neutrino detection with powerful tags of space and time coincidences.

This award will provide funds to test the LENS concept and technology in all its aspects via a relatively inexpensive prototype - Mini-LENS - at 15% of the length-scale (1/300 the volume) of LENS, with the goal of providing a robust characterization of the performance of the technology.

The broader impact on science, technology and education includes: the participation of students and postdocs with opportunities and outlets for curiosity- and imagination-driven research into a physics understanding of the world with simulations, chemical processing, and data acquisition systems. Students will gain valuable hands-on experience working with state-of-the-art instrumentation. Convenient access to the underground laboratory at Kimballton provides excellent training in the intricacies of research underground. The technology of mini-LENS reaches into other realms, and provides new opportunities in other fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was to demonstrate the feasibility of a novel approach for the detection of low-energy neutrinos using a highly-segmented detector by characterizing prototypes such as mini-LENS. The ultimate science objective is to measure the full spectral flux of neutrinos from the Sun, including the low-energy pp neutrinos. This would also test the overall luminosity of the Sun as determined by photons and neutrinos and enable measurement of the CNO neutrino flux, which is key to understanding stellar evolution in multiple stellar environments.  


Towards this end, we developed new detector technologies using metal-loaded scintillators that produce a high yield of optical light in response to ionizing radiation and using optically-segmented geometries that allow precision time and position measurements for the interactions of particles.  A 110 liter prototype instrument based on liquid scintillator was built and operated in a low-background underground environment. Prototypes up to 1 meter in length were also built and tested using external sources of ionizing radiation. Comparison of the measurements with prototypes to computational simulations characterized the performance of the technology for the detection of neutrinos, weakly-interacting fundamental particles.


Our program revealed both promise and challenges to measuring low-energy neutrinos from the Sun.  However, using the technology we developed to measure antineutrinos from nuclear reactors would also provide insight into the nature of neutrinos and the possible existence of  new “sterile” neutrino species. The technology is also of interest for nuclear nonproliferation by providing a passive means to monitor radioactive decay in nuclear reactors at significant distances. A postdoctoral researcher, and many undergraduate and graduate students took significant roles in the project, received training working in a low-background, underground environment, and learned sensitive techniques for the detection of ionizing radiation. One M.S. degree was granted based upon the work supported by this award.
